Award.AwardTitle: Two-Dimensional Infrared Spectroscopy of the Conformational Dynamics of Biomolecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism Program, Prof. Andrei Tokmakoff of the Chemistry Department of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and his graduate student colleagues will develop ultrafast two-dimensional vibrational spectroscopy and use it in conjunction with nanosecond laser temperature-jumps to characterize the conformations of biomolecules and describe their conformational dynamics. These methods will be used to study the folding of NTL9. New methods for studying DNA G-quadruplexes will be developed.

Besides the broader scientific impacts of the research being supported, the research students working on these projects will gain experience with advanced laser techniques. Prof. Tokmakoff also maintains a Web site(http://www.mit.edu/~tokmakof/TDQMS/) through which his most recent quantum mechanics course materials are made available. Additional lecture and laboratory course materials are distributed on the MIT OpenCourseWare Web site(http://ocw.mit.edu/OcwWeb/web/home/home/index.htm/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under NSF grant CHE-1414486, the Tokmakoff group develops ultrafast two-dimensional infrared spectroscopy (2D IR) as a tool to characterize the time-evolving structure of proteins and DNA. Conformational changes are intrinsic to the function of these molecules, but understanding their dynamics (how they change their structure) at a molecular level remains poorly understood. We use 2D IR as a fast camera with a 10-12 second shutter speed, together with modeling and molecular dynamics (MD) simulation to reveal the molecular details of these processes. 2D IR spectroscopy following a nanosecond laser temperature jump allows us to study thermally induced protein conformational changes on nanosecond to millisecond time scales, offering faster time resolution than NMR and more structural information than other optical experiments. 

The scientific activities supported by this grant include (1) protein folding, (2) computational spectroscopy of proteins, (3) membrane protein spectroscopy, (4) DNA tautomerism, and (5) DNA folding and hybridization.  Many of these projects are performed with collaborators in chemical biology and computational biophysics. To provide experimental evidence for new theories of protein folding, we studied the solution phase structure and folding of NTL9 using isotope labeling and Markov state models. We continued the development of a computational model for the amide I IR spectroscopy of proteins, to be used with MD simulations to interpret our experiments. We developed new experimental and computational approaches to use IR spectroscopy to study membrane proteins. We studied the mechanism of action of the HIV anti-viral drug KP1212, a cytosine analogue, providing evidence for the existence of typically rare tautomers that interconvert rapidly. We studied the structure and mechanism of folding G-quadraplexes in the small DNA aptamer TBA, and studied the influence of cytosine post-translational modifications on the stability of DNA. 

Beyond the immediate scientific advances, the broader impacts of this work include the development of human resources and educational material for physical chemists. This grant supported work on projects that involved three postdoctoral scholars, six graduate students, and two undergraduate students, and resulted in one PhD thesis. This grant has helped support the training of all these individuals in the interdisciplinary activities under this project (physical chemistry, laser technology, spectroscopy, molecular biophysics, computational modeling, and properties of molecular condensed matter). Additionally, many of the fundamental topics upon which the funded research is based are being integrated into educational material, including an online textbook on quantum mechanics and spectroscopy (tdqms.uchicago.edu), and a web based resource for teaching biophysical chemistry (bpc.uchicago.edu).
